item.title:
A Russian-owned superyacht is stranded in Norway because local oil suppliers refuse to refuel the ship.
The yacht is owned by the Russian oligarch Vladimir Strzhalkovsky, a former KGB agent and longtime associate of President Vladimir Putin. https://t.co/0rsSijncJ2
The Ukrainian city of Mykolaiv is being shelled every day. Bodies are piled at the morgue. But residents refuse to succumb. https://t.co/QexQVHqA1K https://t.co/dJWhBCE1fj

President Volodymyr Zelensky thanked three NATO-member country leaders who traveled to Ukraine for an extraordinary meeting.
â€œI am sure that with such friends, with such countries, with such neighbors and partners, we will really be able to win,â€ he said.https://t.co/D9iugEXS2c

Zelensky was making an argument about nationhood â€” that it is formed not by history or by language, but by memories and personal connections. â€œNote,â€ he continued, â€œthat Iâ€™m speaking now in Russian, but no one in Russia understands what Iâ€™m talking about.â€ https://t.co/r21OGYVu7W

Ukrainian officials plan to present the U.S. with a list of military equipment they need, including armed drones and mobile air-defense systems, when President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine addresses Congress on Wednesday. https://t.co/NoWN4UApiz

A Russian state television employee who stormed a live broadcast Monday has been fined by a Moscow court for saying in a video that she was â€œdeeply ashamedâ€ to have helped make â€œKremlin propaganda." She still faces a prison sentence over the protest. https://t.co/fFmgkyvmP6 https://t.co/wb2FanGFsa

Francis KÃ©rÃ© has won the Pritzker Prize, architectureâ€™s highest honor. His use of indigenous materials and local symbols to lift up the West African community he came from helped earn him the prize, the jury said. https://t.co/BlBfgDpgzE

Japan, one of the worldâ€™s least friendly countries to refugees, has admitted dozens of Ukrainians who have fled the Russian invasion, officials said. Those who have family or friends already in Japan will be granted a temporary 90-day visa. https://t.co/bDqg1ZahHD

A Russian state television employee who stormed a live broadcast Monday has been fined by a Moscow court for saying in a video that she was â€œdeeply ashamedâ€ to have helped make â€œKremlin propaganda." She still faces a prison sentence over the protest. https://t.co/5Db9fx2HkO

The Senate on Tuesday voted to make Daylight Saving Time permanent. The bill, if made law, would take effect in November 2023, freeing Americans from the biannual ritual of changing clocks. https://t.co/LVF8mmYXk2 https://t.co/8ChOoQtP7o

Brother and sister, Dmytro, 10, and Viktoriia, 8, are among the millions who fled Ukraine. Last week, they arrived for their first day of school in Italy, and students greeted them with tiny Ukrainian and Italian flags they made in classrooms a day prior. https://t.co/2oA7gPH4fF https://t.co/lUr4lJWzmf

In an emotional address to Canadaâ€™s Parliament, President Volodymyr Zelensky urged its members to support a no-fly zone over Ukraine, asking them to imagine cities like Vancouver or Toronto being attacked, and calling for intensifying sanctions on Russia. https://t.co/GCkyJMC85E

Papa Johnâ€™s International said last week that it was suspending all of its corporate operations in Russia, following in the footsteps of other high-profile American brands. But an American who oversees 190 franchises there is keeping them open. https://t.co/HOpQFG8xs4
President Biden will travel to Brussels next week to attend an extraordinary NATO meeting over the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/CDJKoAl7mK
The ballistic missiles that Russia has fired into Ukraine contain a surprise, U.S. officials discovered: previously unknown decoys designed to evade air-defense systems. https://t.co/I9VKdObcMW

Some House Democrats called for an investigation into the postmaster general's decision to buy up to 165,000 gas-powered mail trucks instead of electric over the Biden administration's objections that the contract would undermine the U.S.â€™s climate goals. https://t.co/zmA7xje5ZV

Breaking News: Pierre Zakrzewski, a Fox News cameraman, was killed on Monday in Ukraine when his vehicle came under fire outside of Kyiv, the network said. He was traveling in the same vehicle as Benjamin Hall, a correspondent also injured in the attack. https://t.co/O6BIrxDORf

France could offer diplomatic â€œprotectionâ€ to Marina Ovsyannikova, the Russian state television employee who was detained after an on-air antiwar protest, President Emmanuel Macron said. https://t.co/bsjKcsEg0U
The Fox News correspondent Benjamin Hall was injured on Monday in Ukraine while reporting outside of Kyiv and has been hospitalized, the network said. https://t.co/inxTS1S61C

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine urged Russian troops to surrender.
â€œI give you a chance,â€ he said. â€œIf you surrender to our forces, we will treat you the way people are supposed to be treated â€” as people, decently.â€ https://t.co/eciyOI7ook

Anna Sorokin, the swindler whose fictionalized story was the subject of the Netflix show â€œInventing Anna,â€ will be deported to Germany after she was detained by U.S. immigration authorities for overstaying her visa. https://t.co/gOByFNTKty

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine stepped up his appeals to Russian soldiers and citizens appalled by the war, calling on them to fight to end the conflict.
â€œYou must not lose your chance,â€ Zelensky said, speaking in Russian. https://t.co/6fjKpkLf72

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sent condolences to the family of Brent Renaud, the U.S. journalist who was killed outside Kyiv, thanking the filmmaker for his commitment to documenting the war. https://t.co/NNtvrEU8PE https://t.co/j3YAAW4V80

Breaking News: The leaders of Poland, Slovenia and the Czech Republic said they would meet in Kyiv to express the EUâ€™s â€œunequivocal supportâ€ for Ukraine and offer financial help. https://t.co/QzbSJ9fqvX

Wang Jixian, a Chinese computer programmer living in Ukraine, has become one of the boldest voices challenging Chinaâ€™s skewed and euphemistic depiction of the war. His video dispatches are drawing hundreds of thousands of viewers. https://t.co/7lgVQGbe5v https://t.co/aZyGJkN1SK

After crossing into Moldova from Ukraine, a Ukrainian refugee stared at her countryâ€™s side of the border as she waited for relatives to cross and join her.
Live updates: https://t.co/swiRXtnlLG https://t.co/eVbxmYcM1R

Marina Ovsyannikova, an employee of Russia's state-run Channel 1, burst onto the live broadcast of the network's most-watched news show on Monday evening, yelling "Stop the war!" and holding up a sign that said "Theyâ€™re lying to you here." https://t.co/HrOhKhPjXu

Breaking News: A court in southern India upheld a state ban on hijabs in schools, saying they are not an essential part of religious practice under Islam. The ruling is likely to heighten tensions at a time when India is increasingly polarized. https://t.co/AKfsbSG0hj

Chinaâ€™s top diplomat called on the international community to support peace talks between Russia and Ukraine â€œto help de-escalate the situation as soon as possible,â€ according to a statement. https://t.co/6cDsdDVfkt

Protesters on Sunday broke into a London mansion that is one of the addresses of Oleg Deripaska, the Russian oligarch known for being close to Vladimir Putin. â€œYou occupy Ukraine, we occupy you,â€ a flyer from the self-described anarchists read. https://t.co/md0j6cq0Qd https://t.co/6qi3CtVrlS

The mood is tense in Lithuania, one of the three small Baltic States and NATO members that spent half of the 20th century under Soviet rule. Many there worry that if Ukraine falls, they might be next. https://t.co/dRxAPgeS2r

A man was charged with attempted murder as a hate crime after he assaulted a woman of Asian descent in Yonkers, New York, on Friday. The assault, which was captured by a security camera, marks another incident in a nationwide surge of anti-Asian violence. https://t.co/1KMSve7ALP

Pete Davidson will travel to the edge of space next week on the next Blue Origin spaceflight, the company said on Monday. The "Saturday Night Live" star will be one of six passengers on the companyâ€™s New Shepard rocket for its 20th flight. https://t.co/tHxQiD6oTX

Residents of a severely damaged apartment complex in Kyiv attempted to salvage belongings from their apartments after the attack on Monday. Despite peace talks, Russia launched a flurry of strikes on the Ukrainian capital.
Follow live updates: https://t.co/MPHPxPaHSg https://t.co/F2sjMDV3S2

A document found in the possession of Enrique Tarrio, the former head of the Proud Boys, contained a detailed plan to surveil and storm seven government buildings on Jan. 6, 2021. The plan closely resembled what actually unfolded at the Capitol. https://t.co/tA284dvUMS
Tens of thousands have fled Russia since the invasion of Ukraine, outraged about the war and seeing no future back home. https://t.co/15zXpixg52

A young man fleeing war in Sudan and a young woman evacuating Ukraine crossed into Poland at the same time. They had very different experiences. He said he was beaten and called racial slurs. She wakes up every day to a stocked fridge and fresh bread. https://t.co/oTNeWMi4Tv

Marina Ovsyannikova, an employee of Russia's state-run Channel 1, burst onto the live broadcast of the network's most-watched news show on Monday evening, yelling "Stop the war!" and holding up a sign that said "Theyâ€™re lying to you here." https://t.co/4lLFtZ27Po

A Democratic group said it is filing a formal complaint with the Federal Election Commission accusing Donald Trump of violating campaign finance law by spending political funds on a 2024 presidential bid without formally declaring himself a candidate. https://t.co/G5u4eJQdhi

Protesters on Sunday broke into a London mansion that is one of the addresses of Oleg Deripaska, the Russian oligarch known for being close to Vladimir Putin. â€œYou occupy Ukraine, we occupy you,â€ a flyer from the self-described anarchists read. https://t.co/ndxu2lsBDy

A protester burst onto the set of the live broadcast on Russiaâ€™s state-run Channel 1 on Monday evening. She yelled â€œStop the war! No to war!â€ and held up a sign that said: â€œDonâ€™t believe the propaganda. Theyâ€™re lying to you here.â€
More live updates: https://t.co/amZvf684e6

Hundreds of people escaped Mariupol by car on Monday, according to the local government. An estimated 400,000 people are trapped there without heat, food or clean water as Russia lays siege to the Ukrainian city. https://t.co/0G1TNnNKKr https://t.co/pmJWtSVzr8

Departing from his usual carefully balanced statements, the UN Secretary General AntÃ³nio Guterres said on Monday that Ukraine was being decimated before the eyes of the world and the impact of the war on civilians was â€œreaching terrifying proportions.â€ https://t.co/ErrLVECPkz https://t.co/wJz1pO1Sa0

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine will address Congress in a virtual speech on Wednesday, Democratic leaders said, a move that will likely increase growing momentum on Capitol Hill to pressure President Biden to send fighter jets to Kyiv. https://t.co/v4soTZl71S

Dolly Parton is seeking to take herself out of contention for the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, saying, â€œI donâ€™t feel that I have earned that right.â€ She was among 17 genre-spanning nominees this year. https://t.co/oO71ihDNjc

In Opinion
â€œZelensky and the Ukrainians chose to stand for something, and to be,â€ Maureen Dowd writes. â€œThey are united as a democracy in a way that America has not been for a long time.â€ https://t.co/zKhFChJpGd
Ukraineâ€™s energy minister said Sunday that power supply has been restored at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, which Russian troops have occupied since late February. https://t.co/CYcTISWlz6

The pale pregnant woman photographed after a Russian missile strike on a hospital in Mariupol last week was a grim symbol of Russiaâ€™s intensifying campaign in Ukraine.
The woman and her baby have since died, The Associated Press said on Monday. https://t.co/rCbGPxeaEs
